title: 106_hr3305
content: The Act may be cited as the "Dietary Supplement Fairness in Labeling and Advertising Act". It pertains to the labeling of dietary supplements. The Dietary Supplement Fairness in Labeling and Advertising Act states that Congress believes a proposed rule restricting labeling claims about dietary supplements should not take effect. Dietary supplement labeling exemptions are also discussed. The Dietary Supplement Fairness in Labeling and Advertising Act exempts accurate summaries of findings from peer-reviewed scientific publications from regulation as labeling when used in connection with the sale of dietary supplements to consumers. SEC. 3. ADVERTISING OF DIETARY SUPPLEMENTS. Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act is amended to include regulations on the advertising of dietary supplements and ingredients, defining key terms and providing exemptions from regulation. Exemptions from regulation as advertising include labeling exemptions under the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act and truthful summaries of findings from scientific publications for promotion of dietary supplements. Before the Commission files a complaint alleging non-compliance with the Federal Trade Commission Act regarding advertising for dietary supplements or medical services, the advertiser must have the opportunity to consult with government scientific experts. Before the Commission files a complaint for non-compliance with the Federal Trade Commission Act, advertisers must consult with government scientific experts. Advertising for dietary supplements or medical services can rely on various scientific data, including in vitro studies, animal studies, and preliminary human clinical studies.
